items.title: Is there a way for pylint to bypass checking if Hz is a member of astropy.units?
items.body:
Source:
```
from astropy import units as apu
drift_rate = 2 * apu.Hz / apu.s
print(drift_rate)
```

Python3 execution (correct):
2.0 Hz / s

Pylint 2.5.3 execution:
2:17: E1101: Module 'astropy.units' has no 'Hz' member (no-member)

I realize that there is no way for pylint to know that astropy.units members will be known once the import statement is executed.  So, is there something that I can do, for example, in my $HOME/.config/pylintrc to tell pylint to bypass references to alleged members of astropy.units?

items.title: Detect when an f-string is a plain string
items.body:
<!--
  Hi there! Thank you for wanting to make pylint better.

  Before you submit this, make sure that this feature wasn't
  already requested or if it is not already implemented in the master branch.
-->

### Problem statement
```
variable = f"foo"
```
 Often times when refactoring code it's easy to leave an `f` on a string that doesn't need it. It would be nice if pylint could catch this and display a warning or a refactoring message. 

### Describe the solution you'd like
Essentially the opposite of #2507, but should probably be easier to implement. Raise a warning if an f-string has no expressions.

items.title: Make parameter doc mandatory with docparams and type hints but type doc to be optional
items.body:
## Question

I wish to use `pylint.extensions.docparams` in pylint to enforce docstring documentation with type hints enforced by mypy, and turn off `accept-no-param-doc` to make parameter documentation mandatory. Can I make the parameter type and return type (in docstrings) optional though? It's already being enforced by mypy and so will already be present. (sphinx can possibly also extract it there)

e.g. from the mypy website:

```python
def fib(n: int) -> Iterator[int]:
    """Sample docstring
    :param n: bla n
    :return: sample iterator
    """
    a, b = 0, 1
    while a < n:
        yield a
        a, b = b, a+b
```

I didn't see a `accept-no-param-type-doc` or `accept-no-return-type-doc` switch, or perhaps I should do it a different way?

items.title: imports inside functions are counted as local variables
items.body:
pylint is counting modules imported inside a function as local variables.
Is this the expected behavior? 

### Steps to reproduce
Run pylint on following, contrived examples:
```python
def my_function():

    # Just a bunch of standard libs to demonstrate the issue
    import os
    import glob
    import json
    import csv
    import functools
    import pickle
    import abc
    import threading
    import multiprocessing
    import importlib
    import base64
    import copy
    import warnings
    import shelve
    import subprocess
    import datetime

    print("nothing much here")

```

### Current behavior
pylint outputs
`sketchpad.py:1:0: R0914: Too many local variables (16/15) (too-many-locals)`

### Expected behavior
I would think module is not consider a variable, and thus not included in locals count.

I appreciate use case I presented is artificial, and error at hand can be side-stepped importing modules outside of functions. I also understand importing modules outside of functions is the correct thing to do, I'm not here to argue this point. But I hope to learn if modules are counted as variables on purpose, or if it's a bug.

### pylint --version output

Tested on two version:
```
pylint 2.5.3
astroid 2.4.2
Python 3.8.3 (default, Jun  9 2020, 17:39:39)
[GCC 8.3.0]
```

and 

```
pylint 1.8.2,
astroid 1.6.1
Python 3.6.8 |Anaconda custom (64-bit)| (default, Dec 29 2018, 19:04:46)
[GCC 4.2.1 Compatible Clang 4.0.1 (tags/RELEASE_401/final)]
```

I appreciate that the design stance might be `everything in python is an object, and module is no exception, thus we count it as a local variable in above case and you are experiencing expected behavior`. I can accept that, but it seems somewhat unintuitive to me and thus decided to raise an issue in case this isn't the expected behavior after all.

items.title: Not detecting windows-curses members
items.body:
Greetings all. I would like to note that I have found one other issue of the same type, but it appears to have had no activity for about 6 months now, so I'm opening this one. 

I installed `windows-curses` and started up VSCode to test it out. I use the Python and Code Runner extensions, and installed `pylint` as my linter as I prefer it.

`Pylint` picks up `curses` as an import and all is well, however for most of `curses`' functions/members it claims that they are non-existent. This is false, as the program runs without a hitch.

### Steps to reproduce
1. `pip install windows-curses`
2. create a python script
3. attempt to use a member such as `curs_set()`

### Current behavior
Raises the error: `Module 'curses' has no 'curs_set' member`.

### Expected behavior
No error raised.

### pylint --version output
```
pylint 2.5.3
astroid 2.4.2
Python 3.8.2 (tags/v3.8.2:7b3ab59, Feb 25 2020, 23:03:10) [MSC v1916 64 bit (AMD64)]
```

items.title: W0622 reported on import statement
items.body:
Pylint reports W0622 (redefined-builtin) on the import statement when a redefined builtin is imported into the namespace of the importing module.

Disabling this message on the definition of the redefined builtin still causes the message to be reported on the import statement.

A few versions ago, that did not happen (i.e. Disabling the message on the definition of the redefined builtin caused the message not to be reported on the import statement), but I did not check which version that was.

I do understand the idea behind reporting this, but it is very cumbersome for packages that define builtin symbols in their namespace (!) to deal with that.

### Steps to reproduce
1. `cat pylint_redefined_builtin/__init__.py`
```
"""
Test module for Pylint issue with redefined-builtin reported upon import
"""

from __future__ import absolute_import

from .conn import *  # line 7
```
2. `cat pylint_redefined_builtin/conn.py`
```
"""
Test module for pylint
"""

class ConnectionError(Exception):
    # pylint: disable=redefined-builtin
    "bla"

    def _dummy(self):
        return self
```
3. `pylint pylint_redefined_builtin/*.py`
```
************* Module pylint_redefined_builtin
pylint_redefined_builtin/__init__.py:7:0: W0622: Redefining built-in 'ConnectionError' (redefined-builtin)
```

The same behavior is exhibited when changing the wildcard import to import only `ConnectionError`.

### pylint --version output
pylint 2.5.3
astroid 2.4.2
Python 3.8.2 (default, Mar 11 2020, 00:28:52) 
[Clang 11.0.0 (clang-1100.0.33.17)]

items.title: Since pylint 2.5.0, a report section is no longer produced when jobs!=1

Since Pylint 2.5.0, generating a report is ignored from either source (`--reports` option, `-r` option, `reports` parameter in rcfile) and treated as if specified with no, when jobs != 1.

### Steps to reproduce
0. Have no pylintrc file
1. echo "abc" >try/abc.py
2. pip install pylint==2.4.4
3. pylint -r y -j 4 try/abc.py
   output includes 3 messages and a report section
4. pip install pylint==2.5.0
5. pylint -r y -j 4 try/abc.py
   output includes only 3 messages but no report section
6. pylint -r y -j 1 try/abc.py
   output includes 3 messages and a report section

### Pylint version (when 2.5.0 was installed)
$ pylint --version
pylint 2.5.0
astroid 2.4.2
Python 3.8.2 (default, Mar 11 2020, 00:28:52) 
[Clang 11.0.0 (clang-1100.0.33.17)]

items.title: Pylint 2.5 does not allow ignoring checkers whose names have numbers in them
items.body:
### Steps to reproduce
Using a version of Pylint 2.5, it's impossible to ignore warnings about checkers whose names contain numbers.

Reproducing this requires writing custom checker, which is a bit complicated to describe in a single issue. I've put together a simple reproduction here: https://github.com/jfly/pylint-demo#pylint-checker-naming-issue

### Current behavior

In the demo above, a line like this should pass pylint, but instead I get a `Bad option value '-no-jfly' (bad-option-value)` message. Note that the option value is actually `j3-no-jfly`, *not* `-no-jfly`:

```python
pylint: disable=j3-no-jfly
```

### Expected behavior

I suppose it's possible that Pylint intentionally does not want to support checkers with numbers in their names. That used to be supported, though, so I'd prefer that Pylint support this (as it did in 2.4 and before).

If it *is* intentional to not support numbers in checker names, then I think it would be nice for this to be explicitly called out in a release note, and I also think the error could be clearer about what's going on.

### pylint --version output

(see [readme](https://github.com/jfly/pylint-demo#to-reproduce-the-issue-using-pylint-250) for more information)

```
$ pylint --version
pylint 2.5.0
astroid 2.4.1
Python 3.8.3 (default, May 17 2020, 18:15:42)
[GCC 10.1.0]
```

### Some digging into how this broke between pylint 2.4.4 and 2.5

As demonstrated [here](https://github.com/jfly/pylint-demo), this worked on Pylint 2.4.4, and started breaking with Pylint 2.5.0. I did some code spelunking, and it looks like this commit https://github.com/PyCQA/pylint/commit/9bdae8b82fcc5b0592135cbf6bead7df360a6672 broke support for checkers with numbers in the name. Specifically, it defines `MESSAGE_STRING`'s regex in a way such that numbers are not allowed. One fix may be to just tweak that regex so it allows numbers.

items.title: Warn about redundant 'return None' statements
items.body: This may annoy the hell out of people, but here goes. Python functions that fall off the end of the control flow return `None`. Therefore, if the final line of a function is `return None`, it is redundant. Pylint could emit a warning suggesting the removal of the final line.

items.title: UnicodeDecodeError's object attribute incorrectly reported unsubscriptable
items.body:
<!--
  Hi there! Thank you for discovering and submitting an issue.

  Before you submit this, make sure that the issue doesn't already exist
  or if it is not closed.

  Is your issue fixed on the preview release?: pip install pylint astroid --pre -U

-->

### Steps to reproduce
1. catch `UnicodeDecodeError` as `error`
2. try to subscript `error.object`
3. run through pylint

As far as I understood, and going off of the [documenation](https://docs.python.org/3.6/library/exceptions.html#UnicodeError) which states:

> UnicodeError has attributes that describe the encoding or decoding error. For example, **err.object[err.start:err.end]** gives the particular invalid input that the codec failed on.

This code snippet should be all good:

#### poc.py

```python
"""
UnicodeDecodeError: error.object unsubscriptable?
"""

try:
    raise UnicodeDecodeError("utf-8", b'\xe9', 0, 1, "reason")
except UnicodeDecodeError as error:
    print(f"Cannot decode [{str(error.object[error.start : error.end])}]")
    print(dir(error.object))
```

#### output

Note here: `__getitem__` is implemented.
```bash
$ env/bin/python poc.py
Cannot decode [b'\xe9']
['__add__', '__class__', '__contains__', '__delattr__', '__dir__', '__doc__', '__eq__', '__format__', '__ge__', '__getattribute__', '__getitem__', '__getnewargs__', '__gt__', '__hash__', '__init__', '__init_subclass__', '__iter__', '__le__', '__len__', '__lt__', '__mod__', '__mul__', '__ne__', '__new__', '__reduce__', '__reduce_ex__', '__repr__', '__rmod__', '__rmul__', '__setattr__', '__sizeof__', '__str__', '__subclasshook__', 'capitalize', 'center', 'count', 'decode', 'endswith', 'expandtabs', 'find', 'fromhex', 'hex', 'index', 'isalnum', 'isalpha', 'isdigit', 'islower', 'isspace', 'istitle', 'isupper', 'join', 'ljust', 'lower', 'lstrip', 'maketrans', 'partition', 'replace', 'rfind', 'rindex', 'rjust', 'rpartition', 'rsplit', 'rstrip', 'split', 'splitlines', 'startswith', 'strip', 'swapcase', 'title', 'translate', 'upper', 'zfill']
```

However...

### Current behavior

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/15004223/82567331-8272cb80-9b7d-11ea-9de8-0e64b0d9d746.png)

items.title: W0221 `arguments-differ`: why checking parameter naming?
items.body:
<!--
  Hi there! Thank you for discovering and submitting an issue.

  Before you submit this, make sure that the issue doesn't already exist
  or if it is not closed.

  Is your issue fixed on the preview release?: pip install pylint astroid --pre -U

-->
The `arguments-differ` check is complaining when using a ABC + implicit Generics pattern, involving parameters renaming.
Also asking for an opinion here, this has probably already been discussed here, or in a PEP defined best practices, but I was not able to find where.

### Steps to reproduce
```
class Animal:
   def has_property():
     pass

class Bird(Animal):
   pass

class AbstractGrocery(ABC):
   @abstractmethod
   def deliver_food(self, animal)

class ConcreteBirdGrocery(AbstractGrocery):
    def deliver_food(self, bird):  # adapt the parameter naming for clarity sake
       pass
```
While untyped here and so subject to many confusions, adding type hints would give the same, valid in my opinion.

### Current behavior
`W0221 Parameters differ from overridden 'deliver_food' method [pylint]`

Most probably implemented here: https://github.com/PyCQA/pylint/blob/1fc490c0a1d0df5d4d6a64da0ccf2dd711b9bf67/pylint/checkers/classes.py#L279-L280

### Expected behavior

Since Python doesn't support function overloading, I'd say that as long as the number of args is respected, that's OK.
The naming choice could be bad, but that's another story and out of the scope of pylint anyway.

### pylint --version output
2.4.4

```
            self.show()

```

more detailes:
[https://stackoverflow.com/questions/61775278/pylint-false-positive-class-runtimeerror-wrapped-c-c-object-of-type-qapp](url)

### Expected behavior
The code is totally fine. At least, Pylint 2.4.4 doesn't complain about anything.

items.title: False Positive: Enum.__members__
items.body:
<!--
  Hi there! Thank you for discovering and submitting an issue.

  Before you submit this, make sure that the issue doesn't already exist
  or if it is not closed.

  Is your issue fixed on the preview release?: pip install pylint astroid --pre -U

-->

### Steps to reproduce
1. Create a class like this:

```python
import typing
from enum import Enum


class MyEnum(Enum):
    def to_pb2(self) -> int:
        return typing.cast(int, self.value)

    def __str__(self) -> str:
        return self.name.upper()  # pylint: disable=no-member


class SomeEnum(MyEnum):
    A = "A"


class AnotherEnum(Enum):
    B = "B"


SomeEnum.__members__.items()
AnotherEnum.__members__.items()

```

2. Install pylint 2.5.4 and run: `pylint --errors-only sample_file.py`
3. Install pylint 2.5.2 and run: `pylint --errors-only sample_file.py`


### Current behavior
pylint 2.5.2 raises a no member warning

```
sample_file.py:21:0: E1101: Function '__members__' has no 'items' member (no-member)
```

### Expected behavior
This should not happen

```
Python 3.7.2 (default, Feb  2 2019, 01:42:52)
```

items.title: False positive on continue in finally block (Python 3.8)
items.body:
<!--

### Steps to reproduce
Run `pylint` on the follow code:
```
for i in range(3):
```

items.title: Warning with underscore _ breaks pragma parsing
items.body:
For a particular warning in disable pragma, pylint fails to parse the identifier string. The warning comes from a plugin (pocketlint) and is called `found-_-in-module-class` (note underscore). Instead of disabling, E0012 is emitted and the disable does not happen (obviously). Once the disable is changed to use the numeric identifier `W9902`, the issue goes away.

This regression appeared after updating pylint from 2.4.4. to 2.5.0.

### Steps to reproduce
1. pip3 install --user pocketlint
2. pip3 install --user pylint==2.5.0
3. git clone git@github.com:rhinstaller/anaconda.git
4. cd anaconda
5. git checkout anaconda-33.13-1
6. PYTHONPATH=\`pwd` python3 -m pylint --rcfile tests/pylint/pylintrc anaconda.py
7. Replace `found-_-in-module-class` in the indicated line with `W9902`
8. PYTHONPATH=\`pwd` python3 -m pylint --rcfile tests/pylint/pylintrc anaconda.py

### Current behavior
Buggy behavior:
```
E0012(bad-option-value):anaconda.py:379,0: : Bad option value 'found-'
E0012(bad-option-value):anaconda.py:379,0: : Bad option value '-in-module-class'
W9902(found-_-in-module-class):anaconda.py:381,57: : Found _ call at module/class level
W9902(found-_-in-module-class):anaconda.py:382,35: : Found _ call at module/class level
```
After replacing:
(no output)

See relevant files:
* Reported error location: https://github.com/rhinstaller/anaconda/blob/master/anaconda.py#L379
* Definition of the message: https://github.com/rhinstaller/pocketlint/blob/master/pocketlint/checkers/intl.py#L66

### Expected behavior

No output 

### pylint --version output

```
$ python3 -m pylint --version
pylint 2.5.0
astroid 2.4.1
Python 3.7.7 (default, Mar 13 2020, 21:39:43) 
[GCC 9.2.1 20190827 (Red Hat 9.2.1-1)]
```

items.title: False positive property-with-parameters for an @abstractproperty setter
items.body:
### Steps to reproduce
1. Define the following code with an abstract setter:
```python
"""MyModule."""
from abc import ABC, abstractproperty


class MyClassBase(ABC):
    """MyClassBase."""

    @abstractproperty
    def example(self):
        """Getter."""

    @abstractproperty
    @example.setter
    def example(self, value):
        """Setter."""
```
2. Run pylint on the file

### Current behavior
The following problem is reported for the abstract setter:
```
example.py:14:4: R0206: Cannot have defined parameters for properties (property-with-parameters)
```
Removing the `@abstractproperty` on line 12 makes the `property-with-parameters` problem disappear.

### Expected behavior
It should not report any problem for the definition of the abstract setter as it's correct that it has a parameter to set the value.

### pylint --version output
```console
$ pylint --version
pylint 2.5.2
astroid 2.4.1
Python 3.7.7 (default, Mar 10 2020, 15:43:03)
[Clang 11.0.0 (clang-1100.0.33.17)]
```

items.body:
<!--
  Hi there! Thank you for discovering and submitting an issue.

  Before you submit this, make sure that the issue doesn't already exist
  or if it is not closed.

  Is your issue fixed on the preview release?: pip install pylint astroid --pre -U

-->

### Steps to reproduce
1. code example:
```python
import numpy
data = numpy.load('test.npz', allow_pickle=False)
```

2. run pylint 

### Current behavior
pylint complains: `Unexpected keyword argument 'allow_pickle' in function call pylint(unexpected-keyword-arg)`

### Expected behavior
pylint should not complain about the `allow_pickle` keyword argument for `numpy.load`.
 
However, it could be good to issue a verbose security warning (but not an error) if `allow_pickle` is set to `True` because this poses a security risk [as explained in the numpy documentation](https://numpy.org/doc/stable/reference/generated/numpy.load.html?highlight=load#numpy.load).

### pylint --version output
pylint 2.5.0
astroid 2.4.0
Python 3.7.5 (default, Oct 25 2019, 15:51:11) 
[GCC 7.3.0]
numpy 1.17.3

items.body: As discussed in #3512, removing `bad-continuation` would close https://github.com/PyCQA/pylint/issues/289 which is one of the oldest and most upvoted issues on the repository.

items.body:
I have a cicd that suddenly started failing because tox started bringing in pylint 2.5.0 (I've now pinned it to < 2.5.0).  

I can't share the source code externally so I'll do my best to see if I can track this down just from the stack trace.  I apologize I can't provide steps to reproduce -- I hope this stack trace and the template value being None is enough to track down the cause.

```

    files_or_modules,
  File "/opt/gitlab-runner/NCiG8AGt/0/<path>/.tox/pylint/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pylint/lint/check_parallel.py", line 106, in check_parallel
    linter.reporter.handle_message(msg)
  File "/opt/gitlab-runner/NCiG8AGt/0/<path>/.tox/pylint/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pylint/reporters/text.py", line 151, in handle_message
    self.write_message(msg)
  File "/opt/gitlab-runner/NCiG8AGt/0/<path>/.tox/pylint/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pylint/reporters/text.py", line 141, in write_message
    self.writeln(msg.format(self._template))
  File "/opt/gitlab-runner/NCiG8AGt/0/<path>/.tox/pylint/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pylint/message/message.py", line 51, in format
    return template.format(**dict(zip(self._fields, self)))
AttributeError: 'NoneType' object has no attribute 'format'
ERROR: InvocationError for command /opt/gitlab-runner/NCiG8AGt/0/<path>/.tox/pylint/bin/pylint src/ (exited with code 1)
```

It looks like in message.py, template is None.

In the TextReporter class in text.py, self._template is initialized to be None by the class and not changed, so is passed down to message.py

items.title: False positive `no-value-for-parameter` in Pylint 2.5
items.body:
### Steps to reproduce
In `bug.py`:
```python
"""Whatever"""
import os

def good(*parts):
    """All good"""
    return os.path.join(*parts)

def bad(*parts):
    """False positive below this line"""
    ret = os.path.join(*parts)
    return ret
```
Run `pylint bug.py` (no user config necessary).

### Current behavior
In `Pylint==2.5.0` (see below for detailed versions):
```
************* Module bug
bug.py:10:10: E1120: No value for argument 'a' in function call (no-value-for-parameter)

------------------------------------------------------------------
Your code has been rated at 1.67/10 (previous run: 1.67/10, +0.00)
```

With `Pylint<2.5`:
```

-------------------------------------------------------------------
Your code has been rated at 10.00/10 (previous run: 1.67/10, +8.33)
```

### Expected behavior
`good` and `bad` are effectively the same thing, and both are bug-free. I would expect no errors from Pylint.

Also, I don't get why the argument name is inferred as `a`?
```python
>>> import inspect
>>> inspect.signature(os.path.join)
<Signature (path, *paths)>
```

### pylint --version output
For `Pylint==2.5.0` (first case above):
```
pylint 2.5.0
astroid 2.4.0
Python 3.6.8 (tags/v3.6.8:3c6b436a57, Dec 23 2018, 23:31:17) [MSC v.1916 32 bit (Intel)]
```
For `Pylint<2.5`:
```
pylint 2.4.4
astroid 2.3.3
Python 3.6.8 (tags/v3.6.8:3c6b436a57, Dec 23 2018, 23:31:17) [MSC v.1916 32 bit (Intel)]
```

labels.name: needs reproduction

items.body:
### Steps to reproduce
1. Create a Django sample project using Django 2.2 LTS
2. Locate or implement a `form_valid` function in any class-based view
3. Run pylint check and you will see this failure:
`R0201: Method could be a function (no-self-use)`

### Current behavior


### Expected behavior
The django `form_valid` method is neither a classmethod nor a staticmethod, pylint should not report R0201.

### pylint --version output
```
pylint --version
pylint 2.4.4
astroid 2.3.3
Python 3.8.2 (default, Apr 19 2020, 20:32:10)
[GCC 9.2.0]
```

items.title: Pylint Reports Not shown with -j option in version 2.5.0
items.body:
### Steps to reproduce
```
python3 -m venv venv
source venv/bin/activate
python --version
pip install pylint
export PYTHONPATH=`pwd`
pylint --exit-zero -j 4 --reports=y -f parseable my_files/ tests/ | tee pylint.out
pylint --exit-zero --reports=y -f parseable my_files/ tests/ | tee pylint.out
pip uninstall pylint
pip install pylint==2.4.4
pylint --exit-zero -j 4 --reports=y -f parseable my_files/ tests/ | tee pylint.out
```

### Current behavior
In Pylint 2.4.4 the summary report including Pylint score was shown even when using the -j option to control the number of cores used. 

### Expected behavior
I would expect Pylint 2.5.0 to have the same behavior as 2.4.4 with a valid report along with the score being shown. This score not being shown breaks out CI/CD pipeline where we grep for the score to ensure it stays the same or improves.

### pylint --version output
(venv) [scharman@foomy_repo]$ pylint --version
pylint 2.5.0
astroid 2.4.0
Python 3.6.8 (default, Aug  7 2019, 17:28:10) 
[GCC 4.8.5 20150623 (Red Hat 4.8.5-39)]

items.title: -j0 option broken in pylint 2.5.0  - ImportError: Unable to find module .... in sys.path
items.body:
Hello, the `-j0` option is broken in pylint 2.5.0
This also breaks with any j > 1, thus when multiprocessing is enabled. 

### Steps to reproduce

```bash
# setup venv
cd /tmp
python -m venv venv
source venv/bin/activate
# install
pip install 'pylint==2.5.0'
# create some files
mkdir package
touch package/__init__.py
touch package/file.py
mkdir package/subpackage
touch package/subpackage/__init__.py
```


### Current behavior
```bash
pylint --version
# pylint 2.5.0
# astroid 2.4.0
pylint -j0 ./package
```
Outputs the following:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
```

items.title: Add check to enforce Python 3 no arguments super call style

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: Improvement to a component

items.body:
Python 3 does not require any arguments in calls to `super`, which helps make code more clear in most cases. While there are still use cases for super with arguments, they are very uncommon in most codebases, and junior devs usually include these arguments unconsciously when copying code from other places or out of habit, which may lead to an inconsistent code style.

It would be great for Pylint to optionally enforce no-argument `super` calls. If this is something that the team would be interested in including, I can write a pull request to review.

items.title: Crash when pyproject.toml disable = [ "array", "of", "items" ]

labels.name: topic-configuration
labels.description: Related to configuration

items.body:
<!--
  Hi there! Thank you for discovering and submitting an issue.

  Before you submit this, make sure that the issue doesn't already exist
  or if it is not closed.

  Is your issue fixed on the preview release?: pip install pylint astroid --pre -U

-->

### Steps to reproduce
1. Specify an array of messages to disable in `pyproject.toml`
2. Run pylint

### Current behavior
Crash parsing `pyproject.toml`:

```bash
$ pylint sample
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/Users/bruce/Library/Caches/pypoetry/virtualenvs/ifb-partner-api-AO4b-1bH-py3.8/bin/pylint", line 10, in <module>
    sys.exit(run_pylint())
  File "/Users/bruce/Library/Caches/pypoetry/virtualenvs/ifb-partner-api-AO4b-1bH-py3.8/lib/python3.8/site-packages/pylint/__init__.py", line 22, in run_pylint
    PylintRun(sys.argv[1:])
  File "/Users/bruce/Library/Caches/pypoetry/virtualenvs/ifb-partner-api-AO4b-1bH-py3.8/lib/python3.8/site-packages/pylint/lint/run.py", line 300, in __init__
    linter.load_config_file()
  File "/Users/bruce/Library/Caches/pypoetry/virtualenvs/ifb-partner-api-AO4b-1bH-py3.8/lib/python3.8/site-packages/pylint/config.py", line 785, in load_config_file
    for option, value in parser.items(section):
  File "/usr/local/Cellar/python@3.8/3.8.2/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.8/lib/python3.8/configparser.py", line 859, in items
    return [(option, value_getter(option)) for option in orig_keys]
  File "/usr/local/Cellar/python@3.8/3.8.2/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.8/lib/python3.8/configparser.py", line 859, in <listcomp>
    return [(option, value_getter(option)) for option in orig_keys]
  File "/usr/local/Cellar/python@3.8/3.8.2/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.8/lib/python3.8/configparser.py", line 855, in <lambda>
    value_getter = lambda option: self._interpolation.before_get(self,
  File "/usr/local/Cellar/python@3.8/3.8.2/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.8/lib/python3.8/configparser.py", line 395, in before_get
    self._interpolate_some(parser, option, L, value, section, defaults, 1)
  File "/usr/local/Cellar/python@3.8/3.8.2/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.8/lib/python3.8/configparser.py", line 412, in _interpolate_some
    p = rest.find("%")
AttributeError: 'list' object has no attribute 'find'
```

```toml
[tool.poetry]
name = "fake"
version = "0.1.0"
description = "dummy"
authors = ["Bruce Adams <bruce.adams@acm.org>"]

[tool.poetry.dependencies]
python = "^3.8"
connexion = { extras = ["swagger-ui"], version = "^2.7.0" }
okta_jwt = "^1.3.5"

[tool.poetry.dev-dependencies]
black = "^19.10b0"
fire = "^0.3.1"
mypy = "^0.770"
pyjwt = { extras = ["crypto"], version = "^1.7.1" }
pylint = "^2.5.0"
pytest = "^5.4.1"
pytest-cov = "^2.8.1"

[tool.pylint."MESSAGES CONTROL"]
# bad-continuation - pylint sometimes complains about black's formatting; we go with black
# logging-format-interpolation, logging-fstring-interpolation, logging-not-lazy
# - pylint wants deferred formatting for log messages (to use less CPU if that
#   log level is disabled). We prefer the legibility of f-strings: f"a is {a}"
disable = [
    "bad-continuation",
    "logging-format-interpolation",
    "logging-fstring-interpolation",
    "logging-not-lazy"
]

[build-system]
requires = ["poetry>=1.0"]
build-backend = "poetry.masonry.api"
```

### Expected behavior
What I hope for is that the `pyproject.toml` above behaves the same as when the disable line looks like this.

```
disable = "bad-continuation,logging-format-interpolation,logging-fstring-interpolation,logging-not-lazy"
```

### pylint --version output

```bash
$ pylint --version
pylint 2.5.0
astroid 2.4.0
Python 3.8.2 (default, Mar 11 2020, 00:29:50)
[Clang 11.0.0 (clang-1100.0.33.17)]
```

### Additional information

I tried adding a test for the behavior I want into https://github.com/PyCQA/pylint/blob/master/tests/test_config.py I was _very_ surprised to have that test pass!

I can add that test in a PR, if you'd like. Here it is, just for reference:

```python
import unittest.mock

import pylint.lint


def test_can_read_toml(tmp_path):
    config_file = tmp_path / "pyproject.toml"
    config_file.write_text(
        "[tool.pylint.'messages control']\n"
        "disable='logging-format-interpolation,logging-fstring-interpolation'\n"
        "enable='missing-module-docstring'\n"
        "jobs=10\n"
    )
    linter = pylint.lint.PyLinter()
    linter.global_set_option = unittest.mock.MagicMock()
    linter.read_config_file(str(config_file))

    assert linter.global_set_option.called_with(
        "disable", "logging-format-interpolation"
    )
    assert linter.global_set_option.called_with(
        "disable", "logging-fstring-interpolation"
    )
    assert linter.global_set_option.called_with("enable", "missing-module-docstring")
    assert linter.global_set_option.called_with("jobs", 10)


def test_can_read_toml_array(tmp_path):
    config_file = tmp_path / "pyproject.toml"
    config_file.write_text(
        '[tool.pylint."messages control"]\n'
        'disable=[\n"logging-format-interpolation",\n"logging-fstring-interpolation"\n]\n'
        'enable="missing-module-docstring"\n'
        "jobs=10\n"
    )
    linter = pylint.lint.PyLinter()
    linter.global_set_option = unittest.mock.MagicMock()
    linter.read_config_file(str(config_file))

    assert linter.global_set_option.called_with(
        "disable", "logging-format-interpolation"
    )
    assert linter.global_set_option.called_with(
        "disable", "logging-fstring-interpolation"
    )
    assert linter.global_set_option.called_with("enable", "missing-module-docstring")
    assert linter.global_set_option.called_with("jobs", 10)


def test_can_read_setup_cfg(tmp_path):
    config_file = tmp_path / "setup.cfg"
    config_file.write_text(
        "[pylint.messages control]\n"
        "disable=all\n"
        "enable=missing-module-docstring\n"
        "jobs=10\n"
    )
    linter = pylint.lint.PyLinter()
    linter.global_set_option = unittest.mock.MagicMock()
    linter.read_config_file(str(config_file))

    assert linter.global_set_option.called_with("disable", "all")
    assert linter.global_set_option.called_with("enable", "missing-module-docstring")
    assert linter.global_set_option.called_with("jobs", 10)
```

items.title: Wrong type interference with None
items.body:
<!--
  Hi there! Thank you for discovering and submitting an issue.

  Before you submit this, make sure that the issue doesn't already exist
  or if it is not closed.

  Is your issue fixed on the preview release?: pip install pylint astroid --pre -U

-->

### Steps to reproduce
Example script `test.py`:
```python
from typing import Optional


def test(opt: Optional[int] = None):
    opt = 1 if opt is None else opt
    return -opt


def test_explicit(opt: Optional[int] = None):
    opt: int = 1 if opt is None else opt
    return -opt
```
### Current behavior
test.py:6:11: E1130: bad operand type for unary -: NoneType (invalid-unary-operand-type)
test.py:11:11: E1130: bad operand type for unary -: NoneType (invalid-unary-operand-type)

### Expected behavior
`pylint` infers that we have a actually a value for `opt` and doesn't give errors.

In *my* opinion, `pylint` should at least take the hint if I manually tell it, that it's the correct type.
Having some superfluous type declarations are in *my* opinion better, then having many comments disabling the errors if the type is wrongfully inferred.


### pylint --version output
```
pylint 2.5.0
astroid 2.4.0
Python 3.7.3 (default, Mar 27 2019, 22:11:17) 
[GCC 7.3.0]
```

items.title: Missing return in abstract property fails in pylint 2.5.0

labels.name: crash
labels.description: A bug that makes pylint crash

items.body:
<!--
  Hi there! Thank you for discovering and submitting an issue.

  Before you submit this, make sure that the issue doesn't already exist
  or if it is not closed.

  Is your issue fixed on the preview release?: pip install pylint astroid --pre -U

-->
I have encountered an error when using abstract properties and multiple inheritance. The code itself works in it returns a correct value but it seems that pylint tries to check the abstract property for return which it doesn't have, interestingly the same code without property works with pylint. Adding an empty return statement to C class also fixes this issue.
### Steps to reproduce
Sample Code:
 ```python
from abc import abstractmethod


class A:
    @property
    def test(self):
        return "super"


class C:
    @property
    @abstractmethod
    def test(self):
        "abstract method"


class B(A, C):

    @property
    def test(self):
        try:
            return super().test
        except KeyError:
            x = "x"
            return f"http://%s-production.{x}"

b = B()
print(b.test)
```

### Current behavior

items.title: pylint-2.5.0 cannot parse a class overriding JSONEncoder's default method
items.body:
Hi,

Thanks a lot for all your work on pylint and the related projects!

There have been previous issues raised about pylint's handling of classes that inherit from json.JSONEncoder and override its .default() method, mostly because JSONEncoder is woefully special in having a "default" propertyfor its constructor and then doing something crazy with it. However, at least the previously-reported issues I could find (e.g. https://github.com/PyCQA/pylint/issues/414) are kind of solved by disabling the method-hidden diagnostics for the default() method.

Now it seems that pylint-2.5.0 cannot even parse such a class.

1. Download storpool-5.3.1 from PyPI (https://pypi.org/project/storpool/5.3.1/#files)

3. Change the "pylint" dependency to "pylint != 2.5.0", watch the test pass with pylint-2.4.4.

items.body:
<!--
  Hi there! Thank you for discovering and submitting an issue.

  Before you submit this, make sure that the issue doesn't already exist
  or if it is not closed.

  Is your issue fixed on the preview release?: pip install pylint astroid --pre -U

-->

### Steps to reproduce
1. Create a new .py file with the following contents:
```python
def paused_iter(iterable):
    """Iterate an iterable, yielding the previous item using `i.send(True)`."""
    iterator = iter(iterable)

    while True:
        try:
            value = next(iterator)
        except StopIteration:
            return

        # Continue to yield the same item until `next(i)` or `i.send(False)`
        while (yield value):
            pass


ITERATOR = paused_iter(range(3))
```
2. Run `pylint` on this file.

Pylint reports the following error:

### Expected behavior
The above error does not apply to the above valid code since the function that "returns None" is a generator. Thus, I expect that no such error should be reported.

items.title: assure that repeated errors have unique wording
items.body:
Short story, would it be possible to describe the problem more concretely so
different instances of the same report don't have the same wording?  E.g.

```diff
- Too few public methods (0/2)
+ Too few public methods in ClassName (0/2)
```

Long story, ... before merging any PR, we want to to generate two sets of pylint
issues (before and after applying the patches from PR) and then diff them.  Only
the errors which are new should be fixed before we merge the code.

For generic "static analysis report" diff'ing, there's [csdiff](https://github.com/kdudka/csdiff)
project.  It runs as `csdiff old-report.log new-report.log` and it only
keeps the added (new) issues on it's stdout.

Csdiff ignores line numbers in reports, that's because the code moves all
the time within the same file.

The thing is that in [some situations](https://github.com/kdudka/csdiff/issues/6),
multiple occurrences of the similar issues exist in the same file and
csdiff isn't able to distinguish between them.

items.title: False negative for undefined-variable when attempting to access class scope from comprehension
items.body:
### Steps to reproduce
Consider the following example from the Python execution model reference [here](https://docs.python.org/3/reference/executionmodel.html#resolution-of-names):
```
class A:
    a = 42
    b = list(a + i for i in range(10))
```
As per Python's documentation, executing this file will fail with the message `NameError: name 'a' is not defined`. (The class attribute `a` is considered out of scope from within the body of the generator expression. As of Python3, it would also be out of scope from within the body of a list comprehension.)

### Current behavior
Pylint assumes that the class attribute `a` is visible from within the generator expression, and doesn't give a warning (i.e. a false negative).

### Expected behavior

Pylint should print an `undefined-variable` warning when attempting to access class attributes from within the body of a generator expression or comprehension.

### pylint --version output
```
pylint 2.4.4
astroid 2.3.3
Python 3.7.3 (default, Mar 27 2019, 22:11:17) 
[GCC 7.3.0]
```

### Steps to reproduce
1. Create pyproject.toml
2. Add pylint tooling
```
[tool.pylint.messages_control]
disable = """,
    bad-continuation,
    invalid-name,
    """
```
3. Add black tooling (from black website (https://black.readthedocs.io/en/stable/pyproject_toml.html)[https://black.readthedocs.io/en/stable/pyproject_toml.html]
```
[tool.black]
line-length = 88
target-version = ['py37']
include = '\.pyi?$'
exclude = '''

(
  /(
      \.eggs         # exclude a few common directories in the
    | \.git          # root of the project
    | \.hg
    | \.mypy_cache
    | \.tox
    | \.venv
    | _build
    | buck-out
    | build
    | dist
  )/
  | foo.py           # also separately exclude a file named foo.py in
                     # the root of the project
)
'''
```
4. Run black
```
black --config pyproject.toml .
```
5. Run pylint
```
pylint --rcfile=pyproject.toml foo.py
```

### Current behavior
Running pylint fails. I get the following error.
```
Traceback (most recent call last):

    parser.read_file(fp)

    self._read(f, source)
```

It appears that the parser does not like how black is set-up in the project.toml file.

For pylint to run successfully with black tooling in the same pyproject.toml file.

items.title: cannot configure logging-format-style in pyproject.toml
items.body:
pylint throws an error when adding `logging-format-style` as a configuration option in `pyproject.toml` and trying to lint my project

```
[tool.pylint.messages_control]
disable = """
    bad-continuation,
    wrong-import-position,
    invalid-name,
    line-too-long,
    too-few-public-methods,
    import-outside-toplevel
    """

[tool.pylint.logging]
load-plugins = """
    pylint.extensions.docparams,
    pylint.extensions.mccabe
    """
logging-format-style="fstr"
```
### Steps to reproduce
1. Create a `pyproject.toml` file
2. Add a section named `[tool.pylint.logging]`
3. add `logging-format-style = "fstr"`
4. run pylint as `pylint name_of_package --rcfile pyproject.toml`

an exception is thrown

items.title: Docstring length limit check
items.body:
### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe
I think it would be nice if pylint could have docstrings checked for max length; that is, if it had distinct limits for code length and docstring length.
That would allow compliance with PEP 257 (which suggests 72 characters as length limit for docstrings), independently of the code length limit enforced.

### Describe the solution you'd like
A new error identifier for docstrings that go beyond their own lenght limit.


### Additional context
I'm not familiar with the codebase, but AFAICT the best place for such check would be the docstyle extension.
